header.title: The Magical Treatise of Solomon or Hygromanteia
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Solomonic Magic, Grimoire Tradition

central_thesis: The Magical Treatise of Solomon is identified as a pivotal Greek grimoire that serves as the primary historical and practical source for many later Latin grimoires, most notably the widely disseminated Key of Solomon. The book aims to bridge the understanding between Greek medieval magical traditions and subsequent European ritual magic, thereby clarifying previously perplexing passages and rituals found in derivative works and refuting the myth of a Hebrew original for the Key of Solomon.

structure_content.summary: This section provides historical context, introducing the manuscript as a Greek magical text that influenced later Latin grimoires like the Key of Solomon. It discusses early references, scholarly editions, and abbreviations used for various manuscripts. It also explores the debated etymology and significance of the title 'Hygromanteia'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Analysis of the Contents of the Magical Treatise - Part I: A Method for Talisman Construction
structure_content.summary: Details the theory and practical construction of talismans. This includes methods for determining planetary hours, attributes of the seven planets (benefic, malign, mixed), zodiacal signs, and lunar days for timing operations. It outlines prayers to planets, conjurations of angels, and instructions for preparing ritual instruments and materials such as the black handled knife, reed pens, quills, virgin and unborn parchments, virgin wax, virgin clay, and various planetary inks and incenses.

structure_content.chapter_title: Analysis of the Contents of the Magical Treatise - Part II: The First Method of Evocation
structure_content.summary: Presents a complete ritual for spirit evocation, beginning with moral and physical preparations for the evoker, including confession, ritual baths, and specific garments. It describes the construction and consecration of magical implements like the crown, lamen, and ring. Detailed instructions for tracing the protective magic circle, preparing incenses, and performing conjurations for the appearance of spirits in visible, human form are provided, including specific conjurations for love and treasure.

structure_content.chapter_title: Analysis of the Contents of the Magical Treatise - Part III: The Second Method of Evocation
structure_content.summary: Describes an alternative method of spirit evocation, similar in purpose but differing in specific procedures, ritual attire, and the design of the lamen. It focuses on conjurations directed towards the 'four kings' or chief demons associated with the cardinal directions (East, North, West, South) to compel their appearance and service.

structure_content.chapter_title: Analysis of the Contents of the Magical Treatise - A Miscellany of Occult Techniques
structure_content.summary: Compiles various independent magical operations not strictly part of the core 'Treatise' but found within its associated manuscripts. These include spirit imprisonment in a bottle (Gasteromanteia), evocation of the 'Lady of the Mountains,' and numerous divination methods: water pot divination (Epibaktromanteia/Hygromanteia), basin divination (Lekanomanteia), mirror divination (Katoptromanteia), crystal stone divination (Krystallomanteia), egg divination (Oomanteia), fingernail divination (Onykhomanteia), necromancy (Nekromanteia), and invisibility spells.

key_concepts.definition: The Greek title, literally meaning 'water divination,' though it applies broadly to a system of astrological magic and spirit evocation. It is also linked to the practice of constraining demons in water vessels (hydriai).

Specific periods of time, each ruled by one of the seven planets, crucial for timing magical operations to align with planetary influences and achieve desired outcomes (e.g., love, wealth, healing, harm).

key_concepts.term: Black Handled Knife (Knife of the Art)
key_concepts.definition: A fundamental ritual implement, traditionally made from a sword or knife that brought death and fitted with a black he-goat horn handle. It is used for tracing magical circles, preparing other tools, and its power is believed to banish or repel spirits.

A magical breastplate or seal, often made from unborn calf parchment, inscribed with specific characters and names. It is worn by the magician during evocations for protection and to assert authority over spirits.

Specially prepared animal skins (from unweaned male animals or unborn calves/fawns) used as a pure surface for writing magical texts, characters, and talismans, believed to hold enhanced magical potency.
A hierarchy of powerful demons (e.g., Loutzipher, Beelzeboul, Asmedai, Astaroth) associated with the cardinal directions, who are evoked and commanded in specific rituals to perform various tasks.

A common divinatory technique involving a virgin boy as a medium staring into a water-filled vessel (or bottle) to perceive spirits or visions, often to answer questions about thieves, future events, or hidden treasures.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in The Magical Treatise of Solomon is a complex, hierarchical form of ritual magic focused on the construction of talismans and the evocation and command of spirits (angels and demons). It heavily relies on astrological timing—specifically planetary hours, lunar days, and zodiacal signs—to imbue operations with efficacy. The system mandates strict ritual purity, including fasting and moral conduct, for the magister (operator) and often involves a virgin boy as a medium for divination. The core principle is to bind and compel spirits through divine and barbarous names, using consecrated tools and materials, to achieve various mundane and supernatural ends.

relevant_quotes.text: This is an extremely important book for both the history and the practice of magic in Europe and the Eastern Mediterranean, because it forms the bridge between the Greek magic of the Middle Ages and the later grimoires of Italy and the rest of Europe.
It is in fact this text which is the source of the Key of Solomon, the most widely disseminated grimoire in Europe, from which a whole host of other European grimoires derived.

The work known as The Magical Treatise of Solomon or Hygromanteia is a Greek magical book that survives in a fragmentary form in a number of manuscripts, the earliest of which dates to the 15th century. Its material seems to have influenced posterior Latin grimoires of the West, such as the Key of Solomon and the Grimorium Verum.

Pay attention, my dearest son Rehoboam, to the details of this art, regarding the things in which the entire interest of the Hygromanteia lies ... And Rehoboam asked him: 'Father, in which things does the virtue of things reside?' And Solomon replied: 'In herbs, in words and in stones.'

In fact, the Treatise is not divided in two parts but in three. There are two similar but different methods of evocation, the second being placed immediately after the first. They probably have a common origin.
Not only is it now possible to understand grimoire magic at greater depth, but it is also possible to dispose of the myth that the Key of Solomon was translated from a Hebrew original.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Magical Treatise of Solomon is a foundational text in the study of Western Esotericism and Solomonic magic. Its importance lies in being a direct Greek precursor to the Latin Key of Solomon, revealing the transmission and evolution of grimoire traditions from the Eastern Mediterranean to Europe. The book provides crucial insights into the Greek origins of many magical practices and symbols found in later Solomonic works, thereby challenging long-held assumptions about their Hebrew roots. It acts as a Rosetta Stone for understanding obscure passages in subsequent grimoires by offering their original context and detailing specific ritualistic and material instructions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This book is essential for academic researchers and scholars specializing in Western Esotericism, occult studies, and the history of magic. It also appeals to serious practitioners of Solomonic magic and grimoire traditions who seek a deeper, historically informed understanding of their craft, enabling them to reconstruct or clarify rituals and the underlying philosophy.
